thread.title: Faulkner Roundup: Title for CHS volleyball; CCS and St. Joseph volleyball, CBC and UCA golf
thread.title_full: Faulkner Roundup: Title for CHS volleyball; CCS and St. Joseph volleyball, CBC and UCA golf

author: David McCollum
title: Faulkner Roundup: Title for CHS volleyball; CCS and St. Joseph volleyball, CBC and UCA golf
text:
Faulkner Roundup: Title for CHS volleyball; CCS and St. Joseph volleyball, CBC and UCA golf Posted: October 21, 2015 - 7:26pm By David McCollum LOG CABIN STAFF WRITER 
Conway’s Lady Cats came from behind at Bryant on Tuesday to clinch the 78A/6A Central volleyball title with a victory over the Lady Hornets. 
The Lady Cats (27-5, 12-2) won, 21-25, 25-19, 25-22, 25-21. They now have a first-round bye in the 7A state tournament, which they will host beginning Tuesday. Conway will play at noon Wednesday. 
Against Bryant, Aly Brinkley had 13 kills and Morgan Mourot and McKenzie Hart, 18 assists each. MacKenzie Dear had two aces and 30 digs. Brinkley and Kendahl Davenport had three blocks each. 
The CHS JV completed a perfect conference season with a 25-22, 19-25, 15-9 victory. 
Holly Stewart had nine kills and Aryn Blumenberg 15 assists for the Lady Cats (16-1, 14-0). Morgan Solberg had 18 digs and Ashanti Davis, one block. CBC VOLLEYBALL 
ROSE BUD — Conway Christian’s volleyball tram finished second in 3A-Central after losing in four sets to Atkins in the championship game Tuesday. 
The Lady Eagles downed Harding Academy in the semifinals. 
CCS will begin state tournament play Tuesday at Piggott. CCS TENNIS 
Conway Christian’s Winston Strawn lost , 2-7. 7-6, 6-3, Tuesday to Kade Cushing of Parkers Chapel in the Class 2A boys singles tennis semifinals at the Fort Smith Athletic Club. The CCS boys finished fourth. 
Abby Brickett and Hannah Milligan of Riverside downed CCS’ Mary-Morgan Ellis and Macey Vaught in the girls doubles semifinals, 7-6, 6-4. CBC GOLF 
PANAMA CITY, Fla. — Central Baptist College’s men finished third Wednesday in the National Christian College Athletic Association’s golf championships at Hombre Golf Club here. 
The Mustangs had a three-round total of 930. Colorado College won the national title with a 913, overtaking Dallas Baptist on the final day. CBC’s Austin Harmon tied for fifth overall with a 6-over 227. Other CBC scores were: Luke Cornett, T10, 231; Tyler Pinney, 19th, 235; Joel Futrell, T24th, 239; and Cameron Ressor, T31, 246. UCA MEN’S GOLF 
The University of Central Arkansas women’s golf team finished seventh out of 17 teams on Tuesday at the Middle Tennessee Blue Raider Invitational at Old Fort Golf Club in Murfreesboro, Tenn. Freshman Emma Stevenson tied for 10th place, shooting 74-78-75-227. Sophomore Fernanda Lira was 22nd with rounds of 81-74-76-231, followed by junior Brenda Gonzalez in a tie for 45th (79-77-82-238). Freshman Cindy Oh tied for 58th (84-79-79-242) and junior Morgan Best tied for 72nd (83-81-83-247). 
Host Middle Tennessee won the tournament at 883, followed by Troy (912), Eastern Michigan (922), Tennessee Tech (926), Western Kentucky (927), Little Rock (933), UCA (937), Arkansas State and Murray State (944), UMKC (945), Jacksonville State (947), Austin Peay (948), Boston College and UTEP (952), South Alabama (954), Belmont (983) and UT Rio Grande Valley (1,005). ST. JOSEPH VOLLEYBALL 
ROSE BUD — Harding Academy ended the season for the St. Joseph volleyball team (16-11) with a 25-22, 25-13, 25-20 victory in the quarterfinals of the 3A Central tournament. 
The Lady Bulldogs earlier defeated Lighthouse Academy, 25-17, 25-5, 25-10. 
“Losing to Harding is very disappointing,” said St. Joseph coach Luke Davis. “This keeps us out of the state tournament. That’s one of our main goals and when you don’t reach it, it’s hard to swallow. The girls were pretty upset, too. We had a young team this year. I hope they remember this and go to work to get better.” UCA WOMEN’S GOLF 
The University of Central Arkansas men finished 12th on Tuesday at the Kennesaw State Pinetree Intercollegiate played at the Pinetree Country Club in Kennesaw, Ga. 
UCA freshman Luis Obiols tied for 20th individually, shooting rounds of 77-73-74-224. Freshman Lewis George tied for 23rd at 78-71-76-225, while junior Brad Lamb was 56th (83-78-78-239). Freshman Mason Keller tied for 63rd (82-77-85-244) and sophomore Christopher Fynboe was 67th (101-88-83-272). 
Memphis topped the field at 856, followed by Kennesaw State (860), Lipscomb (877), Jacksonville State (888), Southern Illinois and Florida Gulf Coast (908), Samford (911), Western Kentucky (912), Winthrop (917), Mercer (924), Tennessee Tech (925) and UCA (930).
